close_symbols: struct ResponseDataContext (definition, including types of buf, buf_len, off)
struct Language (definition, including types of dirname and longname)
explanation:
To judge MISRA C pointer-to-const correctness in update_directory we must know the actual declarations and prototypes used by the function so we can determine whether pointers point to const-qualified types when they should or must not point to const when the callee will modify the pointee: 

- struct ResponseDataContext: The code uses rdc.buf (allocated and written into), rdc.buf_len and rdc.off. We must know the declared type of buf (e.g. char * vs const char *) to check if it is incorrectly const-qualified or missing const. Also field types confirm intended mutability.

- struct Language: The code reads language->dirname and language->longname. Their declared types (char * or const char *) determine whether pointers to string literals or mutable buffers are correctly const-qualified when passed to stat(), snprintf(), memcpy(), etc.

- languages (array): The declaration (array of struct Language) is needed to confirm the provenance and constness of dirname/longname values used throughout the loop.

- categories (array): category is assigned from categories[category_idx] and later used as a format argument; its declared type (const char * vs char *) is required to check const correctness.

- INDEX_PAGE_HEADER and INDEX_PAGE_FOOTER: These are used as memcpy sources. memcpy prototype takes const void *src; if these symbols are not const-qualified, MISRA may flag missing const. Their declarations are required.

- list_directory (prototype/signature): Called as list_directory(&rdc, dir_name). We must know whether list_directory will modify the dir_name argument or any buffers reachable through rdc (and whether it expects const char * or char *), because a pointer should not be const-qualified if the callee modifies the pointee.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (prototype/signature): Called with rdc.buf and &free. We need the parameter types (does it accept void *buffer or const void *buffer and what type of free-callback it expects) to determine whether passing a non-const buffer (or passing a buffer declared const) violates const-correctness.

- struct MHD_Response: update_cached_response and mark_as_html operate on MHD_Response pointers; knowing the response type helps verify whether MHD_create_response... returns a pointer type matching update_cached_response and whether any const qualifiers are involved.

- update_cached_response (prototype/signature): Called with either NULL or the response. Its signature will show whether it takes a (const) pointer and whether it will store/modify the response; that affects whether the response object or its buffer must be non-const.

These symbols are the minimal set needed to decide for each pointer used in update_directory whether the pointed-to type should be const-qualified (read-only) or must be non-const because the callee or later code modifies the object.
